Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: What Mr Webb recommends is an extension of the Factories Act of England in the direction of the legislation in New Zealand and Victoria.

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: There is preference to unionists in the New ZealandAct.

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: Mr Webb is speaking of the Victorian Factories Acts, as well as of the New Zealand Arbitration Act. It is well known - that when Mr. Sidney Webb was in Australia he studied well the provisions of the Victorian Factories Act, of which he spoke highly. Here he recommends the adoption in England of an Act which, while it makes no provision it for preference to unionists, is capable of preventing oppression and sweating in various forms and phases.

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF

Speaker: Sir JOHN QUICK
Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: Mr Webb points not only to the New Zealand Act, but to the Victorian Factories Act, as models at which the democracy of the mother country should aim. I did not wish to take up any more time on that branch of the question. But, to sum up my position; in the present state of public affairs, I consider that I and my friend's around me here, who belong to the Liberal-Protectionist Party, are not only justified in our present attitude, but are bound to judge this Ministry not merely by its name, or its personnel, but by its measures, as they are severally submitted. I believe that at the present juncture of affairs, there is no probability of any more workable combination being called into existence, and that it is our duty, as far as we possibly can, to avoid any further violent and revolutionary changes. I consider that, in view of the way in which the Commonwealth has been drifting of late, with so many changes, we are undoubtedly in a position of imminent danger, and that there is a risk of the people losing faith and confidence in and respect foi our Federal institutions, if things, go on On much longer as they are doing. Recently o66 Motion of Want [REPRESENTATIVES.] I read, I think in the Review of Reviews, a statement that the present position of this House almost amounts to' a proof that Australia was not ripe for Federation when it took place. That may be an exaggerated statement of the position of affairs, but certainly it ought to be a warning to us, at any rate to Liberal-Protectionists, to do nothing to endanger the faith of the people in our Federal institutions-that we ought, if we possibly can, rather to restrain our personal inclinations and subordinate them to the interests of the State.

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: So much for that portion of the honourable and learned member's address. May I be permitted now to refer to another matter about which he said a great deal, and on which other honourable members have also spoken. I refer to the famous " MCCay amendment," and preference to unionists. The honourable and learned member for Bendigo has been endeavouring very skilfully to draw an analogy between the Victorian Factories Act and the Wages Boards under that Act, and the proposals of the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill. There is no real analogy between them. When the honourable and learned member says that preference to unionists means the dismissal of non-unionists, he ought to know that under the Victorian Factories Act the very reverse has been the case, and that as a matter of fact,\ have employers and others have taken advantage of the Wages Boards to dismiss unionists. In the district which I represent, there is a very large number of persons connected with the brick, tile, and pottery industry. In order to secure the advantages of the Factories Act, they found it necessary to form a union. Is the honourable and learned member for Bendigo aware that it is impossible for employees to secure the advantages of the Victorian Factories Act, unless they form organizations ? That is a condition necessary under the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill, and it is also a condition necessary under the Victorian Factories Act. When they formed their union, some of the men who had been active in its formation immediately became, to use their own term, " spotted men." I know that one man who had taken an active part in the formation of the union, was immediately dismissed from his employment, and he has never since been able to secure employment in any one of the yards. In another instance an employer conducting one of the yards dismissed every man in his employ who had joined the union. There is not a member of the union in his yard today, and he will not allow members of the union to be employed there. These facts are indisputable. The honourable and learned member for Bendigo cannot deny tbem, because they car: be proved up to the hilt. I say that so far from preference to unionists meaning the dismissal of non-unionists, under our Victorian tories Act, the reverse has the case, and unionists have fered. Had it not been for the man to whom I have referred, and those associated with him, the brick, pottery, and tile-makers of Brunswick and other districts would not today be enjoying the advantages of shorter hours and better pay, than they previously received. The mert who took action in forming the unions have been penalized by being dismissed from their employment, whilst those who did not join the unions are now reaping the advantages of the Act. Is that fair? Surely those who take all the risks in getting advantages for the men are entitled to get some o)f the advantages for themselves which others, without risk or effort, enjoy. also wish to say, in connection with this matter, that the honourable and learned member for Bendigo was most unfair when he said that it would be the endeavour of the Labour Party and those associated with them to turn the unions of Australia into active political agents. Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: We have now a Government in power which professes to have been brought into existence to do three things-to restore responsible government, to institute majority rule, and to bring about the restoration of public confidence. It means, in the words of the honourable and learned member for Bendigo, that the Government is necessarily limited by its composite character, l t is a sort of limited liability government. Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: The late Prime Minister will be able to answer the honourable member for himself when he replies to the debate. The Government have three principal planks in their programme. They propose to oppose Socialism. That is plank No. 1. They propose to fight unionism and the Labour Party-that is plank No. 2. And plank No. 3, and the most important of them all, is their proposal "to get into recess. If they mean to oppose Socialism, do they intend to repeal some of the measures which honourable members who now hold the fate of the Ministry in their hands, helped to put upon the statute-book ? Do they propose to repeal" some of those socialistic measures which were placed on the statute-book by honourable members like The honourable and learned member for Bendigo, and which the members of the free-trade section of the coalition opposite have in past speeches condemned everywhere in Australia? Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF
text: The honourable and learned member for . Bendigo has sought to prove that the Protectionist Partyassociated with himself on the other side of the House! hold the fate of the Ministry in its hand. Is this consistent with that majority rule, which the Prime Minister said was going to be instituted? Where is the majority rule of which we have heard so muchj? There «fe more of minority rule now than there ever was before. The best evidence that we have minority rule lies in the circumstance that the Prime Minister has given half the representation of the Cabinet to one-third of the total number of members supporting the Government. That was done, not so much because the right honourable gentleman desired to institute majority rule, but because he wished to give a sop to the protectionist elernent in Australia, in order to make the protectionists believe that by giving half the representation of his Cabinet to that party, protection in Australia would be safe. If majority rule is to be instituted, the protectionists should alone be represented in the Cabinet. They number two-thirds of the members of this House, and they are in a greater majority in the country. What nonsense it is for honourable members to speak about majority rule, when the fate of the Ministry really lies in the hands of any one honourable member sitting behind it. That has been openly boasted by the honourable and learned member for Bendigo today, and by other honourable members repeatedly during the time the Ministry has been in existence. Let me turn now to another matter about which something has been said, and that is the restoration of public confidence. What did the Prime Minister sav about this business ? He is reported in the Argus of 5th September, under the heading, " The real democracy," to have s a i d Lack of confidence spells lack of employment, and no greater curse than that can f all upon families of working men. My efforts, and of all my colleagues, will be devoted to storation of public confidence, not by reactionary methods, but by keeping on the broad track Australian liberalism. That is a fine, grandiloquent phrase, which in the light of his present proposals means very little. He is going to restore public confidence by declaring fiscal peace, industries are being strangled wholesale, and men are out of employment and are leaving these shores ! The way to restore public confidence would be to find employsays ment for our people, and to retain our population. Victoria has lost during the two years, because of the improper nature of the Commonwealth Tariff, 30,000 sons, of whom 24,000 were adults. If Prime Minister and his Government wish restore public confidence, they must bring back these persons, and others besides, they can do so only by declaring the fiscal truce off, and by giving adequate protection tones. to the industries concerned.

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF

Title: MOTION OF WAN T OF

Will public confidence be restored if the fiscal truce is allowed to continue, and if we fail to grant bonuses for the production of iron ? I do not wish to anticipate any debate which may take place on the latter subject, but the development of our great natural deposits of iron ore would give work to a large number of people, and would supply a great quantity of raw product - to those engaged in engineering and other works. The subject is therefore one which should have the attention of any Government, and more particularly of a Government which claims to be desirous of restoring public confidence.

Title: COMMEMORATION
text: There is one thing on which I can congratulate the Prime Minister, and that is upon the formation of his Cabinet. Title: COMMEMORATION
text: The honourable member is a unificationist.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: COMMEMORATION
text: I am to a great extent a uniiicationist. 1 believe that the present Prime Minister has acted wisely in picking out the best men of his party to form his Cabinet rather than selecting men from the different States. Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: COMMEMORATION
text: It is a very good rule.

Title: COMMEMORATION
text: Yes , to begin with.' Title: COMMEMORATION
text: -What about the honourable member for Wilmot?

Title: COMMEMORATION

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: COMMEMORATION
text: The honourable member must not imagine that the right honourable member for Swan is as hungry for office as are some honourable members on the other side.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: COMMEMORATION
text: I say that the Prime Minister has acted on a good principle, and I am here to defend it. Speaker: Mr REID
Title: COMMEMORATION

Title: COMMEMORATION
